awd_titl_txt: Phase 1 IUCRC University of Notre Dame: Center for Alternative Sustainable and Intelligent Computing (ASIC)
awd_abstract_narration:
Neuromorphic circuits, which mimic the human brain's structure and processing ability on silicon, promise to enable ultralow power, high performance computing. Various key breakthroughs have emerged from exponential advances in computing technology and understanding brains, with increasing interest from governments, research institutes, and business entities. Nonetheless, existing computing architectures can hardly demonstrate universal advantages in a large variety of neuromorphic computing tasks. To address this challenge, this project will build the Center of Alternative Sustainable and Intelligent Computing (ASIC). ASIC is a collaborative industry-university partnership that joins leading industry members with academic researchers to conduct multidisciplinary science and research to enable high performance and energy efficient machine intelligence through novel circuits, architecture, and computation models.

The Center of Alternative Sustainable and Intelligent Computing (ASIC) focuses on alternative computing platforms for cognitive applications, which are in general difficult to be efficiently performed on conventional von Neumann architecture. The ASIC Notre Dame (ASIC-ND) site will focus primarily on neuromorphic computing platforms for telemedicine and healthcare related applications, by leveraging the strong research background and the long-term collaboration with Indiana University School of Medicine and relevant industry sectors. The establishment of ASIC is expected to accelerate the development of new computing diagrams in industry sectors and expedites technology transfer from research discoveries to practical solutions.

ASIC research will have broad impact on the computer and IT industries by introducing alternative computing platforms that complement the conventional computing platforms built on von Neumann architectures in the short term, and position alternative sustainable and intelligent computing equivalents important in long term. The knowledge and expertise developed via ASIC will effectively enable the predicted boom in cognitive applications and their urgent demands for hardware and software support. The talent and expertise of center PIs and the industry partners are integrated to enhance the competence of the center members and accelerate technology transfer.

ASIC research may involve academic and industrial data along with public domain data. This data and the resulting research outputs will be maintained using appropriate best practices for each type of data for a period of three years after the closing of ASIC. A central repository, suitably tagged for appropriate referencing and documentation, will be set up at https://asic.pratt.duke.edu for maintaining the acquired and generated data from center projects. Access to all models and project results will be stored online and made available for downloading in near real time to respond to approved user requests.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The NSF Industry/University Cooperative Research Center of Alternative Sustainable and Intelligent Computing (ASIC) has made groundbreaking strides in developing neuromorphic circuits - computing architectures inspired by the human brain's structure and processing capabilities. These circuits aim to revolutionize computing by enabling ultralow power, high-performance machine intelligence. Over the life of this award, ASIC has fostered collaborative partnerships between academia and industry to advance computing technology, especially for telemedicine and healthcare applications.

Intellectual Merit

Neuromorphic computing has long been limited by the inefficiencies of conventional von Neumann architectures in addressing cognitive applications. ASIC has developed alternative computing platforms tailored for tasks such as telemedicine, which are computationally challenging for traditional systems. At the Notre Dame site (ASIC-ND), research has focused on leveraging neuromorphic platforms to enable high-performance, energy-efficient machine intelligence. This includes exploring novel circuits, architectures, and computation models to address critical challenges in telemedicine and healthcare.

ASIC’s work at Notre Dame site has resulted in significant academic contributions:

  • More than 20 publications in top-tier journals such as Nature Electronics and Nature Machine Intelligence, including 5 collaborative papers co-authored with industry members, demonstrating the seamless integration of academic and industrial expertise.
  • A U.S. patent on hardware and neural architecture co-search with member company EdgeCortix, which highlights the center’s pioneering efforts in technology development.

In recognition of the research excellence, ASIC researchers at Notre Dame have also received numerous awards, including the prestigious 2023 William J. McCalla Best Paper Award at the IEEE/ACM International Conference on Computer-Aided Design, 2023 ACM/IEEE DAC Under-40 Innovators Award, and 2021 IEEE Transactions on Computer Aided Design Donald O Pederson Best Paper Award. These accolades underscore the center’s intellectual contributions and leadership in neuromorphic computing research.

Broader Impacts

ASIC’s work has broader implications for both industry and society. The center has introduced alternative computing platforms that complement traditional systems in the short term and pave the way for sustainable, intelligent computing solutions in the long term. These advancements are expected to support the predicted boom in cognitive applications, such as telemedicine, which require advanced hardware and software integration.

The center’s efforts extend beyond research to include education, outreach, and diversity initiatives:

  • Student Training: ASIC ND site has supported 5 faculty members, 6 postdoctoral researchers, and 5 PhD students. Four PhD students completed their degrees, with two securing internships at industry member companies.
  • Outreach: Dr. Yiyu Shi, the ND site director, delivered 8 AI tutorials to elementary school students, fostering early interest in STEM. Sponsored by the center's industry member Singular Medical, the center organized the ACM/IEEE TinyML Design Contest, engaging over 100 teams from 10+ countries in using AI for ventricular arrhythmia detection.
  • Diversity: The center leveraged Notre Dame’s dual-degree programs with historically Black colleges and universities to improve diversity among undergraduate and graduate students, contributing to a more inclusive research environment.

The ASIC Center has successfully advanced the field of neuromorphic computing while fostering collaboration, inclusivity, and technology transfer. By addressing challenges in telemedicine and healthcare, ASIC has demonstrated the transformative potential of alternative computing platforms. The center’s work exemplifies the power of multidisciplinary research to address pressing societal challenges and lay the foundation for a sustainable and intelligent computing future.
